# Introduction

Visualization of transomic networks helps biological interpretation by
exhibiting where the signal goes [@gehlenborg_visualization_2010].

To understand transomics datasets, Yugi has proposed a method for network
visualization [@yugi_reconstruction_2014] by integrating multiple pathways
in 3D space.

The 3D network visualization was created by VANTED [@rohn_vanted_2012]
and manual operation.
transomics2cytoscape automatically creates the network data for
Cytoscape [@shannon_cytoscape:_2003] and
[Cy3D](http://apps.cytoscape.org/apps/cy3d) renderer
using Cytoscape Automation [@otasek_cytoscape_2019].

## 3D network visualization for transomics

```{r setup}
# suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(dplyr))
# suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(RCy3))
# suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(KEGGREST))
# Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE="en_US.UTF-8") 
library(dplyr)
library(RCy3)
library(KEGGREST)
library(transomics2cytoscape)
kinase2enzyme <- system.file("extdata", "kinase_enzyme.txt",
    package = "transomics2cytoscape")
stylexml <- system.file("extdata", "transomics.xml",
    package = "transomics2cytoscape")
create3Dnetwork(c(rno00010=1, rno00010=200, rno04910=400, rno04910=600),
    kinase2enzyme, stylexml)
```
